Award.AwardTitle: 2016 Plant Cell Dynamics Meeting Nanoscale Imaging to Quantitative Phenomics

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Uncovering fundamental mechanisms of organelle and cell dynamics is required for a comprehensive model of plant growth and development as well as for understanding how plants adapt to their environment. Such knowledge is critical for fundamental advances in basic plant cell biology and promoting future applications to agriculture. The 2016 Plant Cell Dynamics conference, to be held June 21-24 in St. Louis, Mo, will focus on providing opportunities for plant cell biologists to learn quantitative approaches for analyzing cellular dynamics and function, including high-resolution microscopy and computational tools. It will also provide a venue for students, postdoctoral scientists and new investigators to interact with established leaders in the field of plant cell biology, thus providing positive impacts on career development for students and trainees at all levels. By encouraging and supporting attendance of trainees from underrepresented groups, the conference will broaden participation in this developing field, which employs techniques of quantitative, predictive and theory-driven biology, and encourages multidisciplinary approaches at the interface of biology, physics, mathematics, and computer science.

The conference will include keynote talks from experts in the field of plant cell biology on methodology appropriate for quantitative studies that probe how plant cells integrate metabolism, cytoskeletal organization, and vesicle trafficking in overall cellular function. In addition, there will be opportunities for oral and poster presentations by trainees and participation in hands-on workshops on spectral imaging, automated plant phenotyping, quantitative image analysis, and super resolution microscopy using attendee-provided samples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided fellowships that increased the participation of post-doctoral associates, graduates, undergraduate students, and underrepresented groups in a meeting entitled “Midwest Plant Cell Dynamics”. The meeting exposed all participants to cutting edge plant cell biology and the use of quantitative image analyses and computational tools to discover mechanisms underlying cellular processes in plants. The knowledge gained from this research will drive the development of improved crops of agronomic importance improving global food security. Nearly all meeting attendees participated in interactive workshops. Five different workshops were offered on topics including spectral analysis, nano-scale microscopy, high-throughput imaging and analysis of plant growth, automated image analysis, career discussion round table, and industrial lab tours. Special lectures and discussions with scientists responsible for key discoveries in the field were another important part of the meeting. The oral presentation from keynote speaker Dr. Charles Anderson on reciprocal regulatory forces working between the cytoskeleton an the plant cell wall demonstrated the utility and importance of integrating state-of-the-art imaging technologies with molecular modeling to understand the in vivo dynamics of plant cell growth and development. Similarly, in the second keynote address, Dr. Federica Brandizzi emphasized the use of quantitative microscopy and state-of-the-art kinetic analysis to define the dynamics of organelle biogenesis and interaction in plants. An honorary lecture by Dr. Natasha Raikhel provided an inspirational lesson on how a career spent in the pursuit of truth regarding the mechanisms of plant vesicular transport made an indelible mark in our quest for knowledge. Importantly, the meeting also included oral presentations and interactive conversations between over thirty different labs. Presentations were given almost exclusively by graduate students and post-docs, providing an important training opportunity. Poster sessions were also very successful, providing excellent interactions among students, post-docs, and PIs. The NSF fellowships enabled a broad group of scientists to attend the meeting and a post meeting survey indicated that one third of the attendees could attend because of the additional NSF fellowship support, and 70% said it would be a factor in deciding whether or not they could attend the 2017 meeting.
